Jobseekers, this one’s for you.
 Every application, every interview, every follow-up… the pressure is immense.
 And I know what you're thinking: Am I not good enough? 
 But let me tell you, this isn’t about you or your skills. It’s about a broken system where 60% of applicants never hear back. 
 Your mental health is not worth sacrificing for a system that doesn’t acknowledge your worth. 
 Please remember, taking care of yourself is the real priority. 
 Your dream job will come, but for now, breathe. 🌻
Looking for jobs on LinkedIn is like online dating: Full of promises, but in the end, you’re just left ghosted.

LinkedIn scams be like: 'Congratulations, you've been selected for a role you didn’t even apply for!' 
 The catch? Pay Rs. 50,000 for the honor.

sapne dekhna achi baat hai,
lekin job ka sapna dekh ke 'interested' likhna,
yeh toh achi baat nahi hai na?

Next time when I'll be reading some LinkedIn Influencer's story, I am starting from the last line.
If there's a link attached to it, it's most probably a fake one.
Saves me time!

Every time I poured my heart into 5-6 rounds of interviews and faced rejection, it felt like a punch in the gut. The sleepless nights, the endless preparation, all for nothing.

But looking back, I realize it wasn’t nothing. It was the Universe’s way of saying, “Not this one, something better is on the way.”

Every single time, I’ve been shown why that rejection happened.

Doors I thought I wanted to walk through were shut, only to have the right ones swing open.

The kind that aligned with my growth, my values, and my happiness.

At first, it stung. It hurt deeply. But now, when things don’t go as planned, I don’t panic.

I don’t question my worth. I sit back, breathe, and trust. The Universe knows.

I know there's another plan waiting. Something bigger, better, and just for me.

To anyone feeling the weight of rejection: trust that the closed doors are protecting you from something you can’t see right now.

Your path is being cleared for something even more beautiful.

To everyone who's still looking for a job...

I see you. I feel you. 💔

Every rejection email feels like a punch in the gut, and every 'We'll get back to you' sounds more like 'You'll never hear from us.'

But I want you to know, you're not alone in this. 🌸

According to a study, 80% of jobseekers struggle with anxiety and self-doubt during their search. It's normal to feel lost, but it's not the end.

Take breaks, breathe, and remember, this doesn't define you. Your worth is not tied to an offer letter. 💥

Your mental health matters more than any job.

Sometimes, we forget that a company’s brand name doesn’t define someone’s talent. It’s easy to get caught up in the 'big company = big talent' mindset, but that's not always the case.

I’ve had the privilege of working with people from smaller companies (lesser known) who blow me away with their skills and dedication. They don’t need a fancy title or a famous brand behind them to prove their worth.

I've seen the other side too—people in top-tier companies feeling lost, overwhelmed, or stuck, even though the world sees them as 'successful'.

Let’s stop attaching someone’s value to the company they work for. Freshers especially need to hear this—skills are what matter, not the size of the company behind them.

At the end of the day, happiness and growth don’t come from a brand name, they come from doing what you love and constantly improving your craft.

Pros and Cons of Life in the USA

Based on my personal experiences and observations over the past 17 years.

PROS

1. Access to nature right in your backyard. Clean air.

2. A culture of innovation and the opportunity to work with some of the smartest people from around the world.

3. Private space to work distraction-free, with freedom over your personal choices.

4. Better civic sense, law, and order.

5. Financial benefit—especially when visiting India, where the exchange rate multiplies your money by 80.

CONS

1. Visa issues create constant stress. It took 14 years for me to get my green card due to the backlog for India.

2. Poor food quality. Vegetables and other ingredients lack their original taste. Eating stale, frozen food is common.

3. Social isolation, which can be stressful, especially during sickness or challenges.

4. Lack of thrill. Life feels predictable, like a for-loop: Weekdays—work, kids' classes, walk, sleep. Weekends—Costco/Patel brother visits, cleaning, birthday parties, temple visits. While this may be true in India as well, in the USA it is extreme.

5. No concept of bai (maid). You are your own Ramukaka and Shantabai 🤣

Ultimately, happiness is very subjective. It depends on your personality, goals, and experiences. Some people are happy and content, while others regret not moving back.

How has your experience in the USA been so far?

We are not supposed to be stressed at work, in relationships, or life in general.

Why? Because:

'Knowledge is a virtue.' — Socrates

And virtue brings happiness!

We seem to have all the knowledge—from WhatsApp University, LinkedIn, YouTube, and podcasts—yet we still suffer. Why?

Because true knowledge is a deeply internalized understanding that guides action. It's not real knowledge if it's not put into practice.

Let's ask this honest question today: How much time do we spend consuming information versus converting it into knowledge by taking action?

PRINCIPLES have helped me far more than INTELLECT in my entrepreneurship journey.

When I left my last company (Bloomberg), the only income I had was YouTube revenue, just enough to pay my mortgage. AtliQ wasn't profitable yet, and Codebasics didn't even exist.

I didn't have huge savings either.

On the other hand, Bloomberg offered me the option to work only three days a week with a great salary and exceptional health insurance. I would have had four full days to build my side gig. But I chose to go full-time with the thought:

'Will I be doing this 10 years down the road? If not, why do it now?'

Today, both of my companies are profitable. Codebasics (the e-learning company) was built from scratch. Now we have a team of 27 people, with good profit margins, and most importantly, I'm enjoying every single moment of it.

Comfort can be a cage. Intellect might calculate the optimal path within existing constraints, but principles help you break free from them.

Extreme work stress likely contributed to my autoimmune condition.

When I was diagnosed with ulcerative colitis, I told my doctor that no one in my family had this condition. The doctor said, 'We don’t know exactly why it happens, but for many patients, stress is the trigger.'

At that time, I was under a lot of work-related stress.

I struggled for years and at some point I was reduced to 49 Kg from 77 Kg.

It was obvious that no amount of money, visa status, or career success was worth the toll on my health.

I was lucky enough to recover and come back, but today I was saddened to hear about a young girl who likely lost her life due to overworking (according to her family).

We should all advocate for better work-life balance, but in the end, it’s up to each person to take control.

Many people work hard to build new skills but often overlook the skills that help maintain balance, like:

1. Understanding the place of MONEY and CAREER in our life (holistically)

2. Learning how to say NO

3. Leaving a team or company when the environment becomes toxic

4. Being mindful before saying YES to a job offer. Are you accepting that job just because it offers a 40% hike or because the company is popular? Have you accounted for the non-quantifiable aspects of that offer (i.e. work-life balance, how they treat their employees, if work is enjoyable, the vision of their management etc.)?

In the end, NO JOB is worth sacrificing your health!

Having at least one sport in your life can significantly enhance its quality.

Here’s how playing volleyball has helped me:

First, it keeps me physically and mentally fit.

Regular exercise boosts my energy and mood.

Second, it teaches teamwork and communication.

On the court, you learn to trust and rely on others.

Third, it’s a great way to relieve stress.

Focusing on the game helps me forget my worries.

Having a sport in your life is more than just fun.

It’s a powerful tool for personal growth and well-being.

Try incorporating a sport into your routine.

You might be surprised at the positive changes!

Make sure you're looking in the right industry, companies, or locations where your skills are in demand.

Network with professionals, attend industry events and be active on platforms like LinkedIn.

Participate in Open Source, Kaggle, Stack Overflow, and Medium.

Build ONLINE CREDIBILITY!

Remember, sometimes it's not about changing yourself, but about changing your environment and approach.

Here's how I achieved FREEDOM before the age of 40

Freedom means doing what you truly love without constraints on TIME and LOCATION.

1) I dedicated 5-10 hours a week to building a YouTube channel alongside my 9-6 job at Bloomberg. It took 6 years, but the channel grew, giving me the confidence to quit. Online passive teaching = time + location independence.

2) Developed a software and AI services business AtliQ Technologies with my brother. He handled operations while I provided mentorship and funding. After 6 years, we became profitable and now it is going great.

3) Built relationships with like-minded individuals who shared my life, business, and spiritual values, making them partners in my entrepreneurial journey. Shoutout to Bhavin Patel Hemanand Vadivel Karandeep Singh Grover Pranav Trivedi

4) Throughout my career, I treated my time like a precious treasure, skipping time-wasters like binge-watching TV, pointless chats, unnecessary social events, and online deal hunting. Instead, I used that time to learn something new daily, fueling the growth of Codebasics and AtliQ Technologies.

Coming from a middle-class village family in India with no business background, this journey was unique.

This post isn't to boast but to show that with dedication and discipline, achieving freedom is possible.

I still remember a day from my childhood.

We were having lunch when a stranger came to our home asking for directions. My father didn’t know the address, but on that hot summer day, he kindly offered the man buttermilk and lunch. We all ate together with my joint family of 10 people.

We talked as if he were one of our relatives. He left, and we never saw him again.

Today, when someone knocks on the door, a thousand questions race through our minds: Why are they here? What’s their motive? Should I open the door?

The same happens with colleagues at work or strangers we meet in daily life.

While we must stay vigilant because bad things happen, shouldn’t we also remember the boundary between being cautious and being kind?

One reason for this constant doubt is the excessive consumption of information.

'The purpose of media is to make every problem your problem.' - Naval

If we’re always thinking about problems, we lose the space to practice kindness.

Negativity is how media makes money and wins.

Optimism is how humanity thrives.

Your boss could have decades of experience.
But might lack skills to get things done in 2024.

I meet investors: who flaunt their 20 years of experience in the market.
Their defence for everything is: I have decades of experience.

Experience is not a substitute for results.

People should listen to you because of your ability to generate results.
Not because you have 5, 10, 15 years of experience in X.

Experience is only valuable if it translates into performance
But, for many -- it translates into a defence for poor calls.

Interesting fact:

Many Engineers are more experienced than Google itself.
Google started in 1998.
But, many Engineers have more than 30 years of experience.

We live in very uncertain times:

- We can lose our jobs anytime.
- New taxes can be imposed anytime.
- Price can increase (inflation) at any rate.

This is not fear-mongering, these are cold & harsh economic facts.

Observe the last 5 years, you yourself would concur with these points.

The new world today is very different from the pre-pandemic world.
Most of us haven't unfortunately caught up with the reality.

The old model of going to school, finding a job. And becoming a lifer is pretty much dead.

Tim Ferriss predicts a multi-hyphenated world: where a doctor is not JUST a doctor, he/she might be a podcaster, writer (and 5 other different things).

This is not a push that you become a podcaster or don't go to school.
The push is that you prepare yourself better to deal with a more volatile world.

Earlier single-dimensional skills ensured survival.
Now, multi-dimensional skills are need of the hour.

I met an investor who has no source of income. And, lives on a fairly big portfolio.

He was deeply worried about how capital gains are being treated in India.
His point was post 2024 budge: the LTCG on equities have gone up from 10% to 12.5%

This is a 25% increase.

His strategy to live so far: was a systematic withdrawal of X% of his portfolio each year. He would pay a small capital gains. And, live with the rest.

This 25% tax increase for someone like him has killed his retirement plans. And, he is now looking to get back to the workforce.

More importantly he is now worried that this number will not be at 12.5%, it will eventually go to 30%, some day.

Point is: you might plan for retirement today on excel.
But, random taxation will kill it.

We all worry about 10-12% returns on our portfolio or a 10% hike on salary.
But, ignore such big developments.

Solution:
1) Be invested across different asset class
2) Learn about taxation
3) And, at some stage in your career (when you have a big portfolio), be tax optimised.

Taxations are going in 1 direction.
And, we all know which one

If you want to enjoy a better quality of life:

[1] Live in a non-metro in India or
[2] Shift abroad

Indian metros are grossly expensive.
And, offer very little value for money.
This applies to things like education or air quality.

Unfortunately, most of us have to spend time in metros to make money.

This -- however-- does not mean that you are permanently confined to Indian metros.

Start building a plan slowly.
Take some action each day to learn about things like:

- How to work remotely?
- How to invest?
- How to find a job abroad?

Something will click.

At the very least avoid illogical decisions like: locking your future income into EMIs for buying bloated properties in Metros.

There is no point in buying an iPhone, if you are overanalysing your decision.

You will ENJOY your money when you can buy things you like --- without feeling the pinch of spending on it.

You don't need a finance coach to tell you all this.

You will always enjoy your money, if you are spending it wisely.

If the process of spending creates stress, you already know that is not a wise expenditure.

This is not finance, this is common sense.

Live in India vs go abroad? Let me share my practical insights on the same.

[1] For starters, I have actually lived across multiple countries.

[2] Practically going through the journey of building startups. And, working in corporates, here is what I would tell you:-

- India has one of the worst corporate cultures.
- The labour is plenty and jobs are few. This asymmetry give massive power to people in higher positions.
- For 60% the pay, you have to put 150% the work: if you compare it to most of the developed markets: like Singapore, Dubai, Europe etc.

[3] Racism is real if you work abroad. You are in a foreign land. You chose to migrate there. Don't expect equitable treatment.

The world is unfair, get used to it. Your looks, the way you communicate, your connections-- everything matters.

[4] Despite this: there are numerous opportunities to save money, make more switch, grow in career.

There are certain types of jobs (eg. front end investment banking) are very hard to come in India, compared to other locations.

[5] Office politics is everywhere: Indian/abroad it does not matter. Be skilled, if bootlicking is not your thing.

[6] It is a myth: that once you go abroad it is very difficult to find jobs back in India then (maybe for some industries). But, generally: once you have global experiences (and if you are an Indian by passport), finding a job is not an uphill battle.

Yes, if you are trying to get equal salary etc. then of course, that is unlikely to happen.

[7] If you are abroad: you get access to more investable investment options. A classic case study is FDs in India. After tax you get 4.5-5% these days, inflation is close to 4-6%. So basically you lose money in FDs in India.

Many locations like Dubai: FD rates are 4.5-5.5% after tax. Inflation is 2-3%. You actually make money on FDs

We can go onto talk about Cryptos, Bonds etc.
To cut the long-story short: wealth building outside India is much easier.

[8] If you are used to the chaos in India, you would love the organised work environment most countries: eg. Singapore etc offers.

This would be a very different type of an experience, which can't be explained in words.

Some would like it, some might not.

[9] If you wish to start something: should you be in India or abroad? depends on what precisely you are starting.

If you are starting an NBFC firm, you have to be in India (if your target audience is Indian). If you are running a D2C startup, which sources from China and sells in India, you don't need to be in India.

You need to take such nuanced view.

[10] In an uncertain world: diversification is a good hedge. Applies to investing, career and life building.

Inflation is rate of change of prices.
Not absolute increase of prices.

Meaning: if the price goes from:

[1] 100 to 110, that's 10% inflation
[2] If it goes from 110 to 115, that's 4.5% inflation

But, realistically -- prices have gone up by 15%, yet the inflation is 4.5%

Add to this on WHAT products: this entire 10%, 4.5% is calculated (i.e design of the inflation basket)--- inflation can be made to appear whatever you want it to appear.

People don't understand all this complicated math/economics.

And, this makes them keep wondering: inflation number is so low, but my prices are going high. How is this possible?

Well, this is the explanation that you need to keep in mind :)

If you live your life with a victim mentality, most likely you will always be a victim.

Bad boss, lack of time, poor paying jobs are all solvable problems.

[1] If you are unhappy with your job, build gig economy skills (product building, sales).
[2] If you want more free time, learn SAAS/automate your work.
Learn to hire better.
[3] If you are unhappy with taxes, learn about different tax residencies.
And, shift. Why? because you can.

Honestly: demanding what is fair --- hardly get you "fair".

But, if you inculcate the ability to build, build global mobility, diversify your skills & income streams smartly, you would be hard to victimise.

Most problem in life are solvable. You just need to figure out how.

The world is not controlled by people, who have money.
The world is controlled by people, who can borrow almost infinite money (cheap)

Today, the stock market corrected by 3%
In fact the world markets are shaking.

Why? one primary reason is:
That Bank of Japan used to offer a 0% interest rate.
This meant: that money could theoretically be borrowed for free.

They changed this rate from 0.00% to 0.25% (after around a decade) recently.

This meant that people who could borrow money for free, will now have to pay a certain rate for borrowing.

As a result, lesser money flow is expected in stocks.
And, investors are now looking to lower their risk.
